title: Team
text:
Philippe Schwaller joined EPFL as a tenure-track assistant professor in the Institute of Chemical Sciences and Engineering in February 2022. He leads the Laboratory of Artificial Chemical Intelligence, which works on AI-accelerated discovery and synthesis of molecules. Philippe is also a core PI of the NCCR Catalysis, a Swiss centre for sustainable chemistry research, education, and innovation. He belongs to a new generation of scientists with a broad set of skills – in his case a combination of chemistry, materials science, computer science, and experimental research.

5 years at IBM Research – Zurich (with Dr. Teodoro Laino)
PhD (2021) in Chemistry and Molecular Sciences (with Prof. Jean-Louis Reymond), University of Bern
MPhil (2019) in Physics, University of Cambridge
BSc (2014) and MSc (2016) in Materials Science & Engineering, EPFL



 —  —  — 
























AI4Science research fellow
PhD (2021) in deep learning, Ecole Normale Supérieure (ENS) Paris and Facebook AI Research (FAIR)
BSc and MSc in theoretical physics
Research interests include overparameterized neural networks and their applications to computer vision, symbolic mathematics and the natural sciences



 —  —  —

title: Schwaller Group at EPFL
text:
The Laboratory of Artificial Chemical Intelligence (LIAC) is part of the Institute of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering at Ecole Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne (EPFL), Lausanne, Switzerland. The lab is led by Prof. Philippe Schwaller.





In LIAC, we develop artificial intelligence and machine learning approaches for accelerating the synthesis and discovery of novel molecules and materials. We do fundamental science driven by real-world use cases focusing on sustainability.
LIAC is derived from the French lab name (laboratoire d’intelligence artificielle en chimie).

title: Welcome, Paulo!
text:
We are delighted to welcome Paulo Neves as a PhD student! He will share a joint appointment at LIAC and Janssen Pharmaceuticals.

Paulo got his undergraduate degree and master’s degrees in Physics Engineering at NOVA School of Science and Technology in Portugal and is currently a machine learning scientist at Pharmaceuticals.

title: Welcome, Victor!
text:
We are delighted to welcome Victor Sabanza as a PhD student! He will be part of our NCCR Catalysis team and will share a joint appointment at LIAC and the Luterbacher group (LPDC)

Victor got his undergraduate degree in chemistry at the University of La Rioja and his master’s degree in complex systems chemistry at Strasbourg University. Welcome!

title: Potluck
text:
We recently had a lab potluck event!
Everyone brought food to share and it was a perfect way to end the work week!



Before we enjoyed the food and drinks

title: Welcome, Andres!
text:
We are delighted to welcome Andres Camilo Marulanda Bran as a PhD student! He is part of our NCCR Catalysis team.

Andres got his undergraduate degree from Universidad de Antioquia (Medellín, Colombia), worked as an i-Scholar fellow in Prof. Andrew White’s group, and just completed an internship at MPI for Mathematics in the Sciences in Leipzig.

title: Welcome, Junwu!
text:
We have the great pleasure of welcoming Junwu Chen as a new NCCR Catalysis PhD student.

Junwu joins the us from the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) in Beijing. If you want to read some of his previous work, they are available from his Google Scholar profile.
We are super excited to have you here!

title: Welcome, Bojana!
text:
We are delighted to welcome Bojana Rankovic as a PhD student! She will be part of our NCCR Catalysis team.

Bojana got her undergraduate degree in computer science at the University of Belgrade and her master’s in computer science at EPFL. She completed an internship at IBM research and completed her master’s thesis at ETH Zürich. Welcome!

title: Toboganning in Leysin
text:
We recently had our first LIAC winter event!
The team enjoyed an amazing lunch in Leysin village, trying out local fondue specialties and rostï, before heading to toboganning.
It was great to have the whole team together!



Lunch before toboganning





Toboganning

title: Welcome Stéphane!
text:
Stéphane joins LIAC as a AI4Science research fellow! Stéphane completed his PhD in deep learning at the Center for Data Science at ENS Paris and Facebook AI Research (FAIR).



Stéphane

title: Welcome Rebecca!
text:
Rebecca joins LIAC as a joint PhD student with the Laboratory of Protein Design and Immunoengineering (LPDI) working at the exciting intersection of machine learning and biology!



Rebecca

title: Welcome Xu!
text:
Xu joins LIAC to carry out her Bachelor’s thesis! Welcome Xu and we are looking forward to doing great science together!



Xu

title: Welcome Artur, Malte, and Lucien as new project and master’s students!
text:
Artur, Malte, and Lucien join LIAC as project and master’s students! We are looking forward to doing great science together!



Artur





Malte





Lucien

title: Welcome Cheng-Hua!
text:
Cheng-Hua joins LIAC for his master’s thesis! Cool!



Cheng-Hua

title: Welcome, Jeff!
text:
We are delighted to welcome Jeff Guo as a PhD student! He will be part of our NCCR Catalysis team.

Jeff Guo recently completed the grad program at AstraZeneca, where he was working on reinforcement learning for molecular design. Before that he received a MRes in Drug Discovery and Development from Imperial College London and BSc in Chemistry from the McGill University.
For a list of all his publication you can check out his Google Scholar profile

title: Kickoff Group Meeting
text:
Last week we had our kickoff group meeting!
It was awesome to see what our talented group members presented only a few months after starting their PhD and projects.
Say hi to Anna Kapeliukha, who will be with us for 3-month project.
Anna, it’s a great pleasure to have you here!
After the group meeting, we went to a Chinese restaurant and discovered many delicious dishes Junwu had ordered for us. Thanks, Junwu!



Dinner with the LIAC team

title: Welcome, Oliver!
text:
We are delighted to welcome Oliver Schilter as a PhD student! He will be part of our NCCR Catalysis team and will share a joint appointment at LIAC and IBM Research.

Oliver got his undergraduate and master’s degrees in chemical engineering at ETH Zürich. He completed his master’s thesis at MIT and previously interned at Roche and CSL Behring. He is currently based at IBM research. Welcome!

title: Research
text: A full list is available from the following Google Scholar profile.

title: Research
section: Journal articles, workshop papers, and preprints
text:
Journal articles, workshop papers, and preprints


J Guo, P Schwaller. Augmented Memory: Capitalizing on Experience Replay to Accelerate De Novo Molecular Design. 10.26434/chemrxiv-2023-qmqmq-v3, 2023.





AM Bran, S Cox, AD White, P Schwaller. ChemCrow: Augmenting large-language models with chemistry tools. arXiv:2304.05376, 2023.


O Schilter, A Vaucher, P Schwaller, T Laino. Designing catalysts with deep generative models and computational data. A case study for Suzuki cross coupling reactions. Digital Discovery, 2023.





KM Jablonka, P Schwaller, A Ortega-Guerrero, B Smit. Is GPT-3 all you need for low-data discovery in chemistry?. 10.26434/chemrxiv-2023-fw8n4, 2023.

AM Bran, P Schwaller. Differential top-k learning for template-based single-step retrosynthesis. AI for Accelerated Materials Design NeurIPS 2022 workshop, 2022.

S Barthel, M Krenn, Qi Ai, N Carson, A Frei, NC Frey, P Friederich, T Gaudin, AA Gayle, KM Jablonka, RF Lameiro, D Lemm, A Lo, SM Moosavi, JM Napoles-Duarte, AK Nigam, R Pollice, K Rajan, U Schatzschneider, P Schwaller, M Skreta, B Smit, F Strieth-Kalthoff, C Sun, G Tom, GF von Rudolf, A Wang, A White, A Young, R Yu, A Aspuru-Guzik. SELFIES and the future of molecular string representations. Patterns, 2022, 3, 10, 100588.

title: Research
text:

A Toniato, AC Vaucher, P Schwaller, T Laino. Enhancing diversity in language based models for single-step retrosynthesis. Digital Discovery, 2023, Accepted manuscript.


D Probst, P Schwaller, JL Reymond. Reaction classification and yield prediction using the differential reaction fingerprint DRFP. Digital Discovery, 2022, 1, 91-97.

A Thakkar, P Schwaller*. How AI for Synthesis Can Help Tackle Challenges in Molecular Discovery. CHIMIA, 2021, 75, 7-8, 677-678.

AC Vaucher, P Schwaller, J Geluykens, VH Nair, A Iuliano, T Laino. Inferring experimental procedures from text-based representations of chemical reactions. Nature Comm., 2021, 12 (1), 1-11. Editors’ highlight in Computation and Machine Learning for Chemistry. [Blog]. [Code].





P Schwaller*, B Hoover, JL Reymond, H Strobelt, T Laino. Extraction of organic chemistry grammar from unsupervised learning of chemical reactions. Sci. Adv., 2021, 7, 15, abe416. Featured in TechTalks, C&EN. [Code].





P Schwaller*, AC Vaucher, T Laino, JL Reymond. Prediction of Chemical Reaction Yields using Deep Learning. Mach. Learn.: Sci. Technol., 2021, 2, 015016. Invited article for “Machine Learning for Chemical Reactions” focus collection. [Code].

[News & Views]. [Matters Arising]. Synthesis and enabling technologies collection. Featured in C&EN. [Code].

AC Vaucher, F Zipoli, J Geluykens, VH Nair, P Schwaller, T Laino. Automated extraction of chemical synthesis actions from experimental procedures. Nature Comm., 2020, 11 (1), 2041-1723. Editors’ highlight in Computation and Machine Learning for Chemistry. Featured in C&EN. [Blog]. [Code].

P Schwaller*, R Petraglia, V Zullo, V H Nair, R A Haeuselmann, R Pisoni, C Bekas, A Iuliano, T Laino. Predicting retrosynthetic pathways using a combined linguistic model and hyper-graph exploration strategy. Chem. Sci., 2020,11, 3316-3325. [Blog].





VH Nair, P Schwaller, T Laino. Data-driven Chemical Reaction Prediction and Retrosynthesis. Chimia, 2020, 73 (12), 997-1000. Invited article for special “Artificial Intelligence in Swiss Chemical Research” issue.

ACS Central Science Top-10 Most Read Articles in 2020. Featured in C&EN, Chemistry World. [Blog]. [Code].





P Schwaller•*, T Gaudin•, D Lanyi, C Bekas, T Laino. Found in Translation: predicting outcomes of complex organic chemistry reactions using neural sequence-to-sequence models. Chem. Sci., 2018, 9, 6091-609. Chemical Science: Most popular articles 2018-2019. Featured in Chemistry World, IEEE Spectrum, MIT Technology Review, phys.org. [Blog].





M Makha, P Schwaller, K Strassel, SB Anantharaman, F Nüesch, R Hany, J Heier. Insights into photovoltaic properties of ternary organic solar cells from phase diagrams. Sci. Technol. Adv. Mater., 2018, 19, 1, 669–682.


N Mounet, M Gibertini, P Schwaller, D Campi, A Merkys, A Marrazzo, T Sohier, IE Castelli, A Cepellotti, G Pizzi, N Marzari. Two-dimensional materials from high-throughput computational exfoliation of experimentally known compounds. Nature Nanotech., 2018, 13, 246–252. HPC Max Prize 2017. Nature Nanotechnology cover. [News & Views]. Featured in arstechnica, phys.org. [Blog]. [Code].

title: Openings
text:
Are you excited about machine learning applied to chemical sciences? If you interested in a Master thesis or semester project, please contact Prof. Philippe Schwaller via email.
In our lab you can learn how to extract/scrape chemical data, handle it using Python and learn the underlying features using machine learning.

title: Openings
text:
Are you excited about machine learning applied to chemical sciences? If you interested in a Master thesis or semester project, please contact Prof. Philippe Schwaller via email.
In our lab you can learn how to extract/scrape chemical data, handle it using Python and learn the underlying features using machine learning.

SNSF Swiss Postdoctoral Fellowships

title: Rebecca M. Neeser
text:
With a solid background in Pharmaceutical Sciences and specialized knowledge in medicinal chemistry and drug design, I possess the unique ability to integrate computational approaches in the creation of novel small molecules. The interdisciplinary nature of my work, bridging the realms of chemistry, biology, and computer science, is of special interest to me. This interdisciplinarity is further enabled by a joint supervision arrangement between LIAC and LPDI (Laboratory of Protein Design and Immunoengineering). LIAC brings expertise in AI for chemistry, while LPDI offers deep knowledge in structural biology and computational protein design. This collaboration enables me to leverage diverse perspectives and cutting-edge methodologies to drive my research forward.
My main interest lies in the development and application of machine learning tools for drug design. I am driven by the opportunity to address unresolved challenges in drug development and provide support to experimentalists. Through my research, I aim to make a tangible impact by facilitating the discovery and development of innovative therapeutics.
Outside of work, you can find me in the mountains, where I am skiing, hiking or climbing. Additionally, I enjoy live music and exploring new coffee spots all over the world.
I am genuinely excited about the prospect of learning new machine learning methods, contributing to the design of novel drugs, and collaborating with exceptional peers.













Master thesis in the Coley Group at MIT in collaboration with the Schneider Group at ETH Zurich
MSc in Pharmaceutical Sciences from ETH Zurich
BSc in Pharmaceutical Sciences from ETH Zurich

title: Oliver Schilter
text:
With a background in chemical engineering, I have had the privilege of pursuing my research jointly between EPFL and IBM Research in Zürich. My passion lies in exploring the intersection of artificial intelligence (AI) and chemistry, with a particular focus on catalysis.
Throughout my academic journey, I have dedicated myself to understanding and harnessing the power of AI to revolutionize the field of chemistry. By leveraging cutting-edge technologies and computational models, I aim to unravel the complexities of catalytic processes and develop innovative solutions to advance sustainable chemistry.
Beyond the realm of research, I find great joy in engaging in various activities such as Squash, running, and hiking. Additionally, I love exploring the art of cooking, experimenting with flavors and techniques to create delectable dishes that nourish both body and soul.
I am truly excited to be a part of this scientific group, where we can collaborate, exchange ideas, and push the boundaries of scientific knowledge. Together, we can pave the way for transformative advancements in the world of AI-driven chemistry.













Master thesis at Jensen Group at MIT
MSc in Bio & -Chemical Engineering from ETH Zürich
BSc in Chemical Engineering from ETH Zürich
